segments.text: later I think attributed directly to Hitler to try to cut the Allied forces in two and capture the port of Antwerp.
So we were right along the way to Liège and Antwerp.
So that's what presumably the grand strategy was.
By that time, of course, the Germans really didn't have enough resources to pull off that sort of maneuver.
They had far more success than their capability deserved because the weather cooperated with them so well and we couldn't use our Air Force dominance.
Did you capture quite a few German troops?
No, just a few, these parachute troops as far as our artillery battalion was concerned.
Did you ever talk to any German troops?
Did you have an opportunity to talk with any?
No, I didn't.
The ones that were captured were taken to the division
collecting station and turned over to the G2 intelligence people, and I never got involved with that.
Our battalion S2 intelligence officer did.
Yes, because of course any of our troops, any chairman, soldiers, or intelligence information picked up came under the S2 intelligence officer, and I was an S3 fire direction.
Sure.
Didn't get involved in that.
Did your battalion take early heavy casualties during the Battle of the Bulge or was it?
Not one.
Not one?
Didn't lose anybody.
Because they sidestepped you sort of.
That's right and of course we were medium artillery and we were back from the front lines a little bit.
They didn't have any air capability either.
Not by that time, no.

The 19, in fact our battalion I think was only 19 killed or something like that, and that was fairly early after Omaha Beach when one of our ammunition trucks got hit by a bomb from a German bomber one night.
Casualties around there, then we had 100% casualties in our aviation observation planes.
One of them had an accident
in a takeoff where he crashed and burned and another plane was shot down by a MiG fighter.
By what kind of thing?
MiG, the German fighter plane.
Messerschmitt?
Messerschmitt.
It was called MiG.
Is that what you call it?
That's what it's called, yeah.
And of course we first saw the
The jet aircraft from the Germans along about this time too.
What did you think of that?
Well we thought that was fantastic.
Our anti-aircraft fire was just absolutely ineffective against the jet aircraft.
They were so much faster.
But they were pretty effective against the old slow dive bomber types.
Now what happened to the second division after
Battle of the Bulge.
Okay, then the advance was rather rapid right on up to the Rhine River.
Yeah.
And we were stationed near Remagen.
Oh really?
Yeah, the uh the uh of course American one of the American uh mechanized
divisions got to Remoggin and got across the bridge before they could destroy the bridge across the Rhine.
And that was a tremendous advantage.
And we were stationed along the Rhine River at that time and moved up to it fairly rapidly.
At that time- And did you cross the bridge too?
No, that was March of 45.
and that's where I exited.
I was messing around where I didn't have any business.
Got in a little shoe mine and got a hole blown through my right foot, so I got evacuated on March 15th of 45.
Yeah, I was gonna ask you about while you were a patient for it looks like five months.
Yeah, and then got released actually because I got evacuated
to Paris and then to England and then back to the United States.
Sent out to Modesto, California presumably for recovery and commitment to Pacific Theater.
But actually- Basically what happened then is you stepped on a mine?
Stepped on a little old shoe mine, apparently.
When I was just out messing around, it was a beautiful day, March the 15th, and it's strange where we were.
on Orion River, the primary observation post was behind our headquarters.
Very unusual.
On a high hill, and it was right from the headquarters, so I just got out to stroll out to the observation post when I was off duty as fire direction officer.
So I walked up the hill and was messing around the observation post,
Just taking a look, basically.
Just taking a look.
Doing something I didn't have any business doing.
Actually, by that time we had pretty well known that the Germans were defeated and we were looking for souvenirs to bring home.
I saw a German rifle sticking in the ground over in one place.
I went over and pulled this out of the ground, but the Germans had apparently booby trapped around that.
At the time I pulled it out, it was very strange.
I thought it had gone off, and I shot a hole in my foot.
And I didn't really know until later, until the doctors determined that the wound in the foot came from the bottom instead of the top, that it was similar.
The little old shoe mines were similar.
They used rifle bullets.
I shot a hole through my right foot, which
took me out of action for a while.
Yeah, you were lucky that it didn't put a bigger hole in you.
That's right, actually the war was virtually over from then and our 2nd Division wound up in Czechoslovakia before the So then you were under Patton again?
Yes, the division I think was put under Patton again.
I can't remember who the direct commander was at that time.
By that time, Bradley was directly under Eisenhower and had an army group.
But the Remagen Bridge area was a very, very spectacular thing, of course.
That gave a tremendous advantage.
The Germans put everything they could in there to try to destroy that bridge.

which they did, it collapsed after three or four days, but by that time there had been about three other, two or three other ponton bridges put across the brine, so that the crossing was established and was a big factor in the war at that time.
How'd you get along with the French people?
Oh, we didn't see very much of French people.
in the Ardennes in southern France.
You see the Germans were withdrawing as we were fighting.
They were giving up ground grudgingly early on, and we just didn't see very many civilians of any kind.
The Germans, as they pulled back, they'd shoot the cattle and they were
kind of devastating the country as they retreated in the hedgerow country.
Hedgerows were tremendous factors in the early battle.
The biggest surprise the Germans got was some brilliant warrant officer in the second division devised a way for the tanks to cross the hedgerows.

and all of the tanks in the division were taken back during the six weeks we were sitting there and had angle iron probes put up welded on the front of them so that a tank would run these probes into a hedgerow and then when the tracks raised a little bit it just lift the top off those hedgerows so they could go right over the hedgerow one after another.
That was a big factor in the breakout.
Now when we got out of Brest, we did have some contact with French people.
The strangest things happened in war.
When we were down there, we ran out of salt.
We didn't have any salt in the dining hall.
So after Brest fell, we were looking around for what we might buy from the French.
We hadn't had any fresh eggs.
So we went out looking for
eggs, and didn't have any salt.
We also bought a calf from a Frenchman butchered calf.
To have a little meat, fresh meat.
And so our S4 went out looking for salt around.
The Germans had taken up all the salt.
so that the French couldn't withhold food supplies and preserve the salt.
We finally found two pounds of salt in a convent down in that area.
So the French down in that area were friendly, alright.
We did a little business with them, but we just didn't have much contact.
Did you ever get any liberty or any time off?
Well that's a real strange story.
We did have a certain allocation for the battalion to send troops back to Paris.
One of the strangest stories, experiences I had, of course we got the overseas edition of Time Magazine, Newsweek, that sort of thing.
I saw in Time Magazine, in early 1945,
When we were in Lausfeld, Germany, we were there about six weeks or so, as I told you, scattered out a long way where the Battle of the Bulls occurred.
So that was late 1944, and I saw where Westinghouse had resumed production of irons.
So I told one of my talented young fire direction soldiers, I said, write him a letter and ask him to send us one of these irons.
Tell him there's no need to clean up your clothes a little bit.
We're getting a little leave to go to Paris now and all.
So he did, just kind of on a joke.
The damn Westinghouse didn't send us an iron.
They did.
We used it for that purpose, to clean up clothes.
and iron clothes to get soldiers ready to go into Paris, France.
It was an unusual thing.
Did you get into Paris?
Did you get any R&R?
No, not me.
I got into Paris after I was wounded.
I was in the hospital there.
Did any of your troops?
Oh yes, some of our troops did get leave to go to Paris, as I say.
We did use the iron and help them clean up clothes.
Not very many, but the division would have a quota to send on R&R to Paris.
So there was some of that.
Artillery troops are not relieved for R&R.
They are not considered to be under as much stress, and actually they're not.
So artillery is never in reserve.
So you don't have an occasion to be able to relieve a large number of the troops and artillery to send for rest and recreation.
How'd you get along with the German people?

Well, in this, we were stationed in this little town of Lautsfeld, Germany early on, and that's really the only experience I had much with the German people, and of course we, in the case of them getting along with us, we were the dominant factor there.
sure did throw our weight around a little bit there.
Was there a lot of antagonism?
Oh yes, we sure didn't trust them.
They stayed in their houses and they catered to us pretty good.
I had a little meats experience.
One time we requisitioned a hog from one of the people, butchered hog, used a quarter ton trailer for a scalding vat,
our mess heaters to heat the water with butchered hog.
I imagine the United States government paid a lot of money for that hog after the war was over, I don't know.
The Germans
There's no question that during that period of time, we didn't have enough troops to keep the Germans from going back and forth across the front lines.
And I'm certain that some of the people in the little village of Lodsfeld, where we were, informed the German troops of our presence, because we did get some counter-battery fire.
Of course, the most spectacular thing happening long about then was the buzz bombs.
We were kinda stationed right on the path from the launching site toward England.
And one of these- So you could watch these and hear them go?
We could see and hear them and one of them failed and fell about 500 yards from our battalion headquarters at one time.
So we were able to look at it at close range.
It did not explode.
But during that time,
the buzz bomb, the unmanned bomb.
What did you think when you saw all these things going over?
Well, we thought that was a kind of a last gasp weapon.
I don't believe I knew.
We all thought that, well, I'm so sure
add to the devastation of London and the heavy population centers in England, but we didn't think they were much of a factor as far as the tactical troops.
There wasn't any big enough target, you know, for the buzz bombs along the front lines.
They just weren't that accurate.
They weren't that accurate, and
They were designed to be targeted on major cities, because I'm sure they couldn't hit anything within five miles of where they were aimed.
But we thought they were kind of ingenious.
They had military devices, all right.
They certainly were at that time.
Now let's talk about your hospitalization.
I was evacuated to Paris first, just there overnight, and then back to England.
How severe was the wound?
Well, it was just behind my toes, a little hole through the foot.
It, of course, tore up the bones and ligaments in that area.
In England, I can remember very well crawling between clean sheets.
I hadn't seen any of those for 287 days, or whatever it was, 289 days.
What a thrill it was to get in bed with clean sheets.
The army doctors did an outstanding job of cleaning this wound and dressing it.
They took loose skin from
my thigh and covered the wound.
As I started recovering then, I was put on a hospital ship to go back to the United States.
I think we were 11 days in transit there.
First on a hospital train to go to the port.
And man, I was sure that I'd be sent from New York to Temple, Texas or somewhere down in my area.
sure was looking forward to seeing my wife.
And getting back closer to home, so you can imagine.
But I was disappointed when I got put on the hospital train that sent all the way across the United States to California.
You didn't get any leave at all?
Oh well, not then.
I was still hospitalized.
After uh, to
getting to Hammond General Hospital in California.
The ward I was put in had several of my former acquaintances.
Like James E. Monk Vance, who's now in Ag Communications right over here.
Frank Litters, who worked for Texas A&M.
We were in the same ward.
The nurse on that ward is now James E. Vance's wife, so he married our nurse.
There were some other Texas Aggies in that ward.
It was... That you felt comfortable there?
Oh yeah, we played bridge and it was pretty easy living there.
Of course we all thought that
that we probably would get committed to the Pacific Campaign.
What did you think about that?
I mean after being in Warnhoff or in France and in Germany, were you eager or were you resistant?
No, I wasn't eager, but accepted it as a soldier's duty.
We recovered, we'd be recommitted to combat.
I got into New York Harbor on VE Day.
So the war in Europe was over before I got sent to California, Modesto, California, to Hammond General Hospital.
Now when I was given leave, my wife came out to visit me there, and when I was given leave, I was starting back to Texas, and when I was in Los Angeles, California,
I was in Los Angeles on VJ Day, saw the town really celebrate.
I was on my way back for leave then from Hammond General Hospital.
Then came right back and I was reassigned to the hospital at Fort Sam Houston and put on outpatient leave.
until December of 45.
Yeah, but I came back in August and resumed my employment with the Dining Hall Department of Texas A&M in late August or September of 1945.
Okay, let's talk about the end of your military active duty then.
Why'd you decide to get out of the military?
Oh we didn't really, it wasn't any serious consideration.
Very few officers were retained in the military forces, and it was never a thought at all to stay in the army.
Not on my part.
Then why did you decide to stay in the reserves?
Well, I wasn't disillusioned with the military at all.
I'd had a successful career, and I was stimulated by military duty.
Still am.
What was your rank when you were discharged?
Well, I got a terminal promotion to major.
I was a captain.
When I was first called into the Army, there was a sergeant by the name of O'Shea in the school for bakers and cooks, and he and I worked together on menu planning
He was in the headquarters school for Bakers and Cooks, so when I went to San Antonio to be discharged, I went back over there to visit my old friends.
He was a major and I was a captain.
He hadn't been anywhere.
He was still sitting at St.
So he had completed his reserve officer training and got qualified for a commission and outranked me.
But he was a good soldier.
I didn't regret that.
When I first went on active duty, Eisenhower was stationed at Fort St. Houston.
Third Army headquarters was there.
General Kruger, they had what was called the Smith-Young Tower.
leased in San Antonio that's still the tallest building in San Antonio.
Eisenhower was a lieutenant colonel when I first went on duty.
I've often said that there must be something wrong with our promotion system.
He got promoted seven times to my three.
He was a colonel.
Did you have an opportunity to meet Eisenhower?
No, I really didn't.
I got to his headquarters over in London from Northern Ireland.
I had an opportunity to go on leave to London, where the G1 in Eisenhower's headquarters, the personnel officer, was one of my old ROTC instructors named Lloyd Garrison.
So I lived with him for a few days in his apartment up in the middle of London, not very far from Buckingham Palace.
So I did get a look at Eisenhower's headquarters in London, all right, but I never met the man.
Now I met his son.
John, just a few years ago, I was at the Army War College with his son John, who later made Brigadier General too.
He was a reserve officer, so we were at the same course at the Army War College.
I would imagine that the troops had very high regard for Eisenhower.
No question.
Why is that?
Well, I really don't know, except that he was generally perceived as doing a fine job in the most demanding military role ever in history.
Stars and Stripes, all the press he got was quite favorable, so I'd say that there's 100% respect and admiration of Eisenhower.
What about General Marshall?
Well, he was pretty remote.
We didn't have really any feeling for General Marshall.
One of our previous division commanders was named John C.H.
Lee.
He was commander of the troops.
He was a very religious sort of a guy and unusual.
He commanded the second division at Fort Sam Houston for a while and later was promoted lieutenant general and was logistic officer and communications zone headquarters.
and because of his initials and his devotion to religion, all the troops called him Jesus Christ himself.
JCH Lee called him Jesus Christ himself.
He wasn't a very outstanding combat commander.
Later on we had an artillery commander by the name of Hayes, and he
By golly, I believe he won the Medal of Honor in World War I.
No kidding.
And he was a tremendous combat leader.
We had him as Artillery Division Artillery Commander for just about a month after we got into combat.
He was pulled out and given the 10th Mountain Division, brought back to the United States and made it Division Commander.
we saw where that division was committed in Italy and we said, well it won't be long until they'll stir things up in Italy because he was a fighter.
That was true.
He was, then he was deputy commander to Lucius Clay after, in Berlin.
He was a tremendous soldier.
He transformed
Division artillery, the second division from kind of parade ground troops into fighting.
Could you compare the quality of the army in World War II with the quality of the German army?
The German army varied tremendously in quality because they had the SS troops, the panzer troops, and then they had the satellite troops and everything.
But their elite troops were fanatical, disciplined soldiers that would, without question, do whatever the commander said.
No American troops were ever that way.
The strength of the American soldier was his independent thinking, his ingenuity,
Not blind loyalty, blind obedience, blind discipline.
Mechanical ability, but you know that's the way I'd characterize the American troops is most of them were not professional soldiers.
I'd say they were a little more difficult to lead.
Even in those days when
There was much more inclination to accept authority than there is today.
There wasn't blind acceptance of authority at all.
Of course we had some black troops and in those days they did not have a very good reputation.
It was probably a bad mistake to have all black troops led by white officers.
when I decided to make a transfer back to the artillery.
I told you earlier that Colonel Bilsing was a good friend of mine and showed me possibly a little favoritism as a senior cadet.
I helped him teach agitation.
So I found out that he was division commander of, I mean division artillery commander of a division stationed at Fort Huachuca, Arizona.
So I telephoned him and I decided to transfer to find out if he needed any officers in his outfit.
He could definitely get a transfer because I had such admiration for the man.
He said, well O.D.
you don't want to get in this outfit, it is a black outfit and we have trouble with troop discipline and troop competence.
What year was this?
That was 42.
That was early, you see I put in for transfer in early 42 after December the 7th.
And the transfer really didn't occur until April of 42, so I just didn't try to exercise any preference at all on the transfer.
Just let them transfer me where they would.
So I got transferred from the

post-camp and station troops of Fort Sam Houston with the school for Bakers and Cooks as an 8th Army outfit, 8th Corps outfit, I mean out in the 3rd Army over to the division right there just around the corner from where the headquarters was.
